content: HackMD created https://hackmd.io/j8EsXGI1RiOnjZSiSRf3ng
@WG-learning ^^^ This is the doc for the overview chapter... please add your questions to it
I added some initial thoughts, but I am not 100% sure of their correctness...
Thank you! I add a section for a flowchart of the same just in case we forget
@mark-i-m I'm having now thoughts about Overview and Walkthrough
what do you guys consider that should be included in one and in the other?
From what I understand, Overview is abstract steps and Walkthrough is by example code(s).
Not sure if I my understanding correct.
I was actually wondering if it makes sense to have them as two separate chapters... I was thinking we could just have 1
yes, this is what I meant too
you can probably describe some things in the abstract but then go into a concrete example
I was thinking of two chapters because I was hoping to have multiple levels of code examples.
From simpler to more complex
If we merge these two into one, I would love to have sub-chapters for an example each under this. What do you think?
I'd say that as soon as we figure out this first thing we can think about the rest ?
Oh sure! I am not saying we have to get to that this second. :slight_smile: Sorry if I came off that way.

Hi all, I updated the overview section notes a lot. In particular, I broke out two sections (1) what the compiler does to your code and (2) how it does it. Please let me know what you think of this organization
Any thoughts?
gonna read it again
@mark-i-m everything is https://hackmd.io/j8EsXGI1RiOnjZSiSRf3ng right?
gonna read it again later
Yes, thanks!
This is shaping up great @mark-i-m !
Do you think that it is far enough along to push the document to a branch of the rustc-dev-guide repository? I'd like to point to the working branch in the blog post if possible
Hmm... I guess it could be
Personally, I vaguely prefer the hackmd, but I do see the benefits of gh for getting feedback
Anyone else interested in the lexer & parser sections? If not, I can work on those areas.

Chris Simpkins said:

Anyone else interested in the lexer & parser sections? If not, I can work on those areas.

Centril and I are getting together later this week to discuss the parser. I'll begin adding parser Overview documentation after the meeting.
WIP: https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-dev-guide/pull/659 (based on @mark-i-m branch)

@mark-i-m Do you want to periodically merge commits in other PR's into your downstream repository so that we can base changes on your open PR branch or is there a better approach? Do you have access to push your open PR branch into an upstream working branch so that we can continue to rebase on it as changes get pulled in?
Hi @Chris Simpkins I was wondering about that too. It's a bit tricky
I can make a branch on the rustc-dev-guide repo, but we will lose all of the review history already there and the link from the blog post will be wrong

I think the easiest would be either

  1. for me merge your changes into the current PR branch
  2. to merge my PR and rebase yours onto master

between the two, I prefer 1. I think you WG members should also have permission to push onto my branch too
or alternately, we could just keep going with the two different PRs and have one big rebase at the end?
actually, I'm starting to lean towards (2) and open a bunch of followup PRs
(1) works for me too. I am fine with whatever approach works best on your end. I am only trying to avoid significant merge conflicts. I have no concerns about frequent merges and opening new PR's.
or (2) ... :slight_smile:
Hmm let me post on your PR thread then. If it's ok with petrochenkov/centril/matklad, I guess we can try (1) which seems simplest and go to other models if it doesn't work
I think that will minimize conflicts
and you should have access to my branch so you can make changes for parsing and lexing as needed
Ty! I will rebase once I see how you handle it. I should have another PR this weekend with the parser text.

I spoke with @matklad today about the lexer Overview. I’ll update the Overview section this evening. I have enough information to begin work on the Guide lexer / parser chapter edits at this stage too.
Thanks @Chris Simpkins!
I think there is a question we should collectively address: how much detail should the overview have?
e.g. I feel that the current amount/detail of content is sufficient, but perhaps others feel it is too high-level?
cc @WG-rustc-dev-guide ^^
I think we should nail this down so that we are all on the same page
hmmm, isn't it supposed to be high level so we can go into details on each section chapter?

Santiago Pastorino said:

hmmm, isn't it supposed to be high level so we can go into details on each section chapter?

SGTM. We have a detailed outline for much of the Overview now. Do we want to decide what bits should stay and what should transition into the chapters? For the stages, maybe a one / two liner summary, entry point link, and Guide chapter link?
Part of the problem that I had is that it just isn't quite as simple as a one/two liner :slight_smile:
I'll need to re-read the chapter
I should probably also re read the whole thing. Perhaps at next week's meeting we can go by paragraph/bullet (1min per) and vote to add more, shorten, or leave unchanged

Hmm, so I just gave it a reread, and I do feel that we have the right amount of details in the list of steps and shouldn't add more. In fact, I think we should maybe even move some of the content on the cmd line parser to the rustc driver chapter. e.g. I don't feel that we should mention entry points are specific structs in the list of steps (we don't even mention TyCtxt)
I would even go so far as to say we should try to address the todos in the current document and then ship it

I can update the sections that I wrote to address those comments this evening. Will push a new PR with the updates. I'll need to take a look through the rustc_interface chapter to see where things fit.
And I plan to work on the lexer and parser chapter in the Guide. I likely won't get to this before the weekend.
Thanks @Chris Simpkins! I think these will be great additions to the driver, parser, and lexer chapters!
I've got a good deal more for the chapter itself after the discussions with _@centril and _@matklad. Let's see what I can come up with. They both offered to review when it is ready.

I'm at the stage where it would be helpful to dive into the source and start tinkering with it to really understand it. Trying to identify some relatively straightforward lexer/parser issues to work on. The chapter will shape up as I do that.
That reminds me that we still have content from a discussion with petrochenkov about macro expansion and hygiene that needs to be turned into a proper chapter too
/me realizes how big the compiler is...

mark-i-m said:

That reminds me that we still have content from a discussion with petrochenkov about macro expansion and hygiene that needs to be turned into a proper chapter too

You're pretty familiar with expansion too AIUI?
@mark-i-m didn't get it properly if you consider the overview chapter ready
I meant, there's always stuff to do but we can also merge and keep improving it

@Santiago Pastorino I think there are a few important TODOs we should address before merging, but other than that, I think it looks pretty good imho:

  • niko or eddyb or some other all-around expert should take a look and confirm that we didn't say anything incorrect
  • we should determine what level of detail to put about cmdline args, lexer, and parser and finish those points
  • we need to confirm where trait solving and const eval happen and put in points about those
  • we should figure out what to do about the "unresolved questions" section. Do we just open an issue for them?
Will work on the interface, lexer, parser section over the weekend. Let me know if you have thoughts about the level of detail.
Quick update. Got sidetracked and haven't gotten to this yet. Any other thoughts about the details in the Overview for these revisions?
Oh
So I just addressed most of the remaining comments (except for Santiago's most recent ones)
And I cherry-picked two of @Chris Simpkins commits because I thought we already had a little bit about parsing/lexing etc, but now I see that it was a todo
should I just go ahead and merge the parser PR into the main one?
Eh, I just went ahead and merged it into the big branch, we can streamline later as discussed in the meeting
Ok, I addressed some comments, merged suggestions, responded to others, and added the rest to followup PR
eddyb mentioned that they are pretty busy, so I don't think we will get a review from them soon. And we've had a bunch of other experienced contributors comment on various parts.
I think we should go ahead and merge
At 37 commits and 145 comments, this is probably one of the biggest PR threads we've had on this repo!
SGTM!
:tada: https://rustc-dev-guide.rust-lang.org/overview.html
I'm so proud of it!
:tada: :clap:
Now we need to adress the TODOs
